subject: The Perl Oasis in 4 days + YAPC::NA 2012 CFP + The Modern Perl book headed to the printer
header: Last week I got a bit of negative feedback for a job post being in the subject line. I hope that this one will be received better.
A few days ago I posted my TODO list for 2012. Including the publishing of this newsletter every week. So now I am committed for the next 52 issues :)
You remember the discount for my Beginner Perl Maven course ends today. So make sure you take advantage of it in time.
In other news, we are quickly approaching 2500 members. Thank you all for your support!

entries.title: Beginning Perl - Table of Contents
entries.text: Curtis 'Ovid' Poe is writing a new Perl book for Wrox. This is the table of contents.

entries.title: The Perls of 2011
entries.text: Breno G. de Oliveira (Garu) has posted a detailed and awesome overview of what happened in the Perl community in 2011.

entries.title: YAPC::NA 2012 Call For Presenters Now Open!
Submit your OSCON proposals this week
entries.text: brian d foy gave a list of ideas what to talk about at OSCON.

entries.title: perlformance
entries.text: Renormalist who also calls himself Steffen Schwigon has been talking about a performance metric for Perl for at least 2 year. I am always amazed by people who can run a project with very little publicly seen result for such a long time and then come up with a comprehensive thing. As I understand having a standard way to measure the performance of perl can be important to some vendors. Hopefully it will be interesting to people who are being involved in the development of perl as well.

entries.title: Hunting down a memory leak
entries.text: Sebastian Willing (Sewi) takes us on a tour of a simple looking Perl code that had a memory leak and shows us how to eliminate that.

entries.title: Modern::Perl Updates
entries.text: chromatic explained some of the new features of his Modern::Perl module and mentioned that the new edition of his Modern Perl book went to the printer and will be available soon.

entries.title: Stepping Up (or how to become a co-maintainer of a CPAN module)
entries.text: Buddy Burden just became a co-maintainer of Test::File together with schwern and brian d foy. This was a good opportunity for him to reflect on the whole CPAN ecosystem thing and how easy it is - after all - to give something back to the community.

entries.title: What! No Lexer?
entries.text: Jeffrey Kegler writes about the apparent lack of lexer in Marpa::XS.

entries.title: Skipping Test::Class tests in abstract base classes
entries.text: by Curtis 'Ovid' Poe

entries.title: I love CPAN Testers!
entries.text: Me too. But see how Joel Berger could fix a bug in one of his CPAN modules, even before it hit the end users and without the need to install 20 versions of Perl.

entries.title: Minimal requirement to build a sane CPAN package
entries.text: (szabgab) I encounter people who have already written a module or two and now they are considering uploading them to CPAN or just packaging them for easier distribution. In this article I show the minimal step for a simple pure-Perl module.

entries.title: What you should know about signal based timeouts
entries.text: Do you want to risk a seg-fault in your code? Leon Timmermans shows how safe and unsafe signal handles work and explains what are the problems with either of those.

entries.title: Perl::Critic finds annoying little bugs in your code.
entries.text: Andy Lester posted a use-case of a new Perl::Critic policy. It's always good to see Perl::Critic getting more fail-cases.

entries.title: Perl Script to Convert an Audiobook (m4b) to mp3 files splitting on the chapters
entries.text: From Jason L. Froebe - Tech tips and How Tos for Fellow Techies

entries.title: State of Dancer on Perl 6
entries.text: Apparently now that the Advent calendars are done the number of Perl 6 related posts also dramatically went down. This one is about Bailador, the Perl 6 implementation of the Dancer web framework.

entries.title: What do I need to learn to use WebGUI 8
entries.text: You should really read the short post for this but if you don't have time for that, here is the hint: Template::Toolkit, Moose, Plack and nginx.

entries.title: Ruby (and other) conference talks - API design talks
entries.text: Steven Haryanto shared a link to ConFreaks, a web site with lots of recorded conference talks. Most of the conferences are Ruby related.

entries.title: Google+ Page for YAPC::NA
entries.text: JT Smith announced the Google+ page I created for YAPC::NA. If you are interested in updates about the Perl conferences and Workshops in North America, put this page in your circles. I'll re-post the YAPC::NA blog and I'll also post other, related items and about the Perl Workshops in North America.
